title: Will the rate of new daily confirmed cases of COVID-19 per 100k people in Massachusetts be higher on 19 October 2021 than it was on 7 September 2021?
possible_answers: Yes, having first fallen below 18.5 new cases per 100k people in Massachusetts
Yes, but without having first fallen below 18.5 new cases per 100k people in Massachusetts
No, having first risen above 28.5 new cases per 100k people in Massachusetts
No, but without having first risen above 28.5 new cases per 100k people in Massachusetts
correct_answer: No, having first risen above 28.5 new cases per 100k people in Massachusetts
preds: Based on the NYT data provided by @belikewater , it looks like the 1-day number reported tomorrow will be in the low 40s (maybe "42.7"?). That should bring the 7-day average for the 18th to around 26 ("26.3"?). The 19th will see a sharp decline and will probably be around 20 causing the question to resolve for bin 3. Holding out 5% in bin 1 in case the NYT data is somehow incomplete. https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1345589
Case counts for the weekend seem to be really, really low. Taking the plunge.
Final forecast. I'm going to jump all in on the under.

In case you haven't seen this (I hadn't until now), we might be able to get an early look at cases here:
https://www.mass.gov/info-details/covid-19-response-reporting
"Updated Monday-Friday by 5 p.m."
This page gives the number of confirmed cases for Oct 14 as 1,512 and the number of probable cases as 137, which sums to 1649, the same as the nytimes number for new cases on Oct 14 shown here:
https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2021/us/massachusetts-covid-cases.html
So you can get earlier case numbers from the nytimes web page, not scaled per 100k like our resolution data, but I think we can figure that out. Also note that the resolution data says "confirmed cases," so it may exclude probable cases.
Confirmed + probable:
Oct 13: 1763
Oct 14: 1789
Oct 15: 1649
Average: 1734
The mass.gov page only goes through Oct 14, so it will likely only give data through Oct 17 by 5pm today, but at least that would give us something.
@JonathanMann @paulm @Ryan-Beck @Emking @meterplech @oracle100 Update: The new totals posted are 2815 confirmed, 176 probable. I believe these numbers are for Oct 15, 16 and 17, because the previous number was for Oct 14.
Combining with nytimes data for Oct 13 and 14, which includes probable cases, I get 6543 total, or 1309 average. With a population of 7,029,917 for MA, that's 18.6 cases per 100,000 for those 5 days. We still need Monday and Tuesday, but it looks like cases are declining. I'm revising my forecast back towards bin 3.
There is room for 86.4 over the rest of the period to stay under (21.6/day). It's going to be close.

Going up a bit on the first bucket. The number to beat from September 7th is 23.4. Currently at 20.2. The trend of Monday postings has declined from around 73 at the peak to about 48 on the Monday before the recent holiday. I'm guessing we'll see a number in the 50s for today which would mean the number for tomorrow just has to be below around 30 to keep the average below 23.4. That seems very doable, there hasn't been a non-monday/holiday weekly number above 30 since September 17th when case counts were higher. Could be wrong about today being in the 50s though, we'll see what happens!

The current 7-day avg is being brought down by the low number on the 11th. The avg over the last 4 days is 24.4 (which is above Sept 7) and with the risk of a correction spike, plus dropping that data from the 11th, I think there's a much higher chance of this falling into Bin 1 than is being accounted for at this point.

@belikewater thanks for pointing out the risk of a jump based on backfill.  I moved my forecast to be way more likely to go over (from ~14% to 34%).  My reasoning in not going higher is that the overall trend in population is likely flat for today, with a prior declining count for the past week based on https://covidestim.org/us/MA. Assuming flat a spike in backfill should be 1/7th of the days in this projection, and while we'll lose the drop day, we'd need the spike to be at ~45 per 100k to go over. There have been a few spike days before that were below that.  This was a crazy question that I am sure to lose Brier score on a lot though. Tough forecast!
Following the others on this a bit, though it seems unlikely that the moving average is above tomorrow after today's spike.

it could go either way and the confidence I have in my intuition that it will fall on the side of bin 1 isn't enough to justify the extra risk of giving it a slight edge, so sliding down to 50 / 50 : https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1344807
Still hypotheticals in the air and all theory. Still uncertain about what Oct 19 will be after the spike on Oct 8. Cases still trending downard. My gut is still 50/50.

Well, this is the question that just keeps giving (a headache mainly). Summing up, I think there is consensus that bin2 is out, for four good reasons; 
1 As stipulated in the first sentence of the question, "The outcome will be determined using data as provided by 91-DIVOC (91-DIVOC, parameters are set with the link)"
2 The dropdown menu below the chart states that the data we are seeing represents "New cases 1-wk average"
3 Alongside the Y axis it says "7-day average"
4 The data is in fact showing a 7-day rolling average (as confirmed by @Emking et al.)
Case for defence rests. Prosecution claims that the labelling is not consistent on the pop-up for each day and can be misleading. 
So it's either bin1 or bin3 for me. The next part is whether the spike which will appear on the 18th will be succeeded by a pronounced enough drop on the 19th to get back below 23.4. I have two trains of thought on this, but overall it looks like it will be very close.  Looking at 'New cases/Day' the reading on 10/13 is relatively high, and this will be the first day that counts in the final 7-day average. Usually, the day after the lumped post-weekend reading is lower than the remainder of the week, so I think the readings on 10/11 and 10/12 may be higher than preceding weeks due to the knock-on effect of the three zero-rated days. It's a slightly weak argument for expecting the reading tomorrow (10/18) to be something lower than 64/100k, and the following day to also be lower than on 10/13.  I'm assuming that the overall trend is declining, but flat for the purposes of this week, to play safe. A mid-point of the prior two Mondays is 55.4, and an equivalent Tuesday would be around 21. Lump this with the three days we already have readings for and we have 152.8 for the week.
On this basis the average should be close to 22.8/100k The other train of thought is that it is too tight to call and any reading higher than 60 tomorrow will very likely to push this into bin3. 
And that has only happened once since this question has been running ...

Ok, I was at 100% on bin 3 for quite a while on this question. Have I learned my lesson about that yet? Apparently not.
We know 3 values that will count for this question so far: 28, 25.7, 23.7. The trend in those numbers may be downward, but if MA is overall heading upward or flat, this could easily resolve to bin 1.
Thanks to @JonathanMann for the nudge.

My gut is almost 50/50, or as close to @JonathanMann's forecast here: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1344807 But I will slowly transition to this line of thinking as I haven't gone all the way up to bin 3 yet so I think I'm at a good spot to hover before committing if at all.

This could really go either way, but, if the true underlying case counts average 22 per day or more from now to the question expiration, this will resolve as bin 1. Nulls make the data tricky to parse, but look at today's count in the daily numbers. I had originally anticipated a ramp up culminating in a "data bomb" spike on the 18th, but, due to nulls, there will be no ramp up. Counts will remain exactly as they are today for the next two iterations and then suddenly *bam* "data bomb" spike for the 18th (appearing the morning of the 19th, unless there is a serious decline in real underlying cases). The 19th (appearing the 20th) will be lower than the 18th, but could still end up at a place where bin 1 resolves as true when the question resolves (slight edge for bin 1 over bin 3 as per my forecast).

28/100k on the 13th, 25.7 on the 14th. So 7 day average is already looking above. Dropped to 13.4 on the 11th so if its above and dropped below 18.5 the Bin 1 seems the way to go... but the data from the 11th is odd... soooo this is going to be a daily watch kinda question and we're all going to get bad scores....

Prepare to see a "data bomb" spike on the 18th and then a sudden drop on the 19th.  Bin 1 is a legitimate possibility. will this forecast trigger an information cascade? Many thanks to @belikewater , @Ryan-Beck , and @Emking for figuring out the chart label issue. Edit: I originally anticipated a steep ramp-up starting today but forgot about the underlying data weirdness caused by the nulls. Data bomb will happen on the 18th (and appear the 19th as pertaining to the 18th)

Even with clarification, there's still disagreement amongst ourselves about whether bin 2 is ruled out, so I'm taking the position that the person who rules on the GJ question could go either way. I'm still optimistic that cases won't rise above 9/7 levels, but I'm hedging against the possibility that they do.
After much discussion, I'm going with bin 2 having been ruled out.
Adding a percent to bucket 2 in case GJOpen makes a weird decision on this one since the last clarification seems kind of confusing and ambiguous.
With two of the five data points in, this week is currently -2% versus the base week. The Monday value will be the critical one, and we won't have time to respond to it.

Looks like a data issue made October 11 drop below 18.5. Still looks likely to stay below the September 7th number but leaving probability on it being above in case of data issue or a quick rise in cases.

It may be that bin 2 is not ruled out, because a 7-day average has not been provided by the data source for Oct 11. I got a partial clarification but am awaiting confirmation that the source must provide the 7-day average.
Note that for the peak on 9/13, a 7-day average was provided, so that definitely counts.
Reassessing what might happen next week after the spike on Oct. 18.

Not clear to me yet whether the value for Oct. 11 will count as an "average over the past seven days," as that is not how it's labeled. I have asked for a clarification.
We can expect a spike on Oct. 18 that will bump up the average on Oct. 19, though. If cases don't decline more this week, this question could well resolve to yes.

The lack of reporting on Columbus day made the 7-day average for Oct 11th consist of only four data points rather than five. Thus, because the lack of weekend reporting is counted as zero rather than null, bin 2 has been eliminated. There will be a spike next Monday, pushing the average up to 26 cases per day (as that day will include an extra day in the calculation). But, the value should drop back under 21 on October 19th as the data catches up.  So far, the data for this week is 5% below the week of Sept. 7th. With only four data points remaining, there is a lot of room for the numbers to swing. If October 14th data comes in above 25 cases per 100k, I will greatly adjust my forecast toward bin 1. If it's below 24, bin 3 is almost certain.
Later edit: Data bomb on 10/11! Not sure whether this means cases will pop up 10/18.

Currently at 20.3.  Extremely unlikely it has time to dip below 18.5 then come back up in the given timeframe but its still possible it could still go above 23.4 as the trend has been up for the last few days (23.7, 24.8, 26.2 in the last 3 days). Will have to watch closely as this question comes to a close.

22.1 as of Oct. 1 and dropping (Was 23.4 on Sept 7). Trend has been downward for last 2 weeks and seems to be accelerating. Would be an unusual blip to swing back up at this point, but as with all covid questions I can't rule anything out.
Zeroing out bin 1, which I think would only be possible now with a testing glitch like around Labor Day.
9/29 7 day was 23.5.  Downward trend. 18 days left.
Updating based on trajectory and current numbers.
I haven't built a model for this, but I'm wondering if things will stay where they are for a few weeks.
Misunderstood the bins, re-allocating to align with previous analysis.

Cases dropping off fairly quickly now; without a change the linear trend would be below 9/7 numbers with a few days to spare. It's also a little more likely now that cases will drop below the 18.5 number - that would be faster than I expect but not implausible.

The only reason I think the answer won't be bin 3 is if there's some bizarre reporting glitch. While those can happen and obviously do happen around big holidays, I don't see any reason why one *should* happen in the next 26 days.
26 days left, with no giant holiday in the forecast period.
Shoot. I got my percentages reversed, was thinking question was on oct 19 lower not higher.
It looks likely that MA has peaked. I expect the decline to be slower than the rise but that cases on Oct 19 will be lower in the end.
9/07 7 day rate 23.4. 9/17 7 day rate was 28.6.  30 days to do. Trend looks flat to down.

Looks increasingly clear that the peak of the Delta wave has already passed. It's 14 days into the forecast period, and 28 more days to go. While the decline will likely be slower than the rise, it will likely not be more than twice as slow.

42 days between Sept 7 and Oct 19. It hasn't been clear exactly when the Delta wave in MA will peak. If it peaks around Sept 28, then if the decline is slower than the rise, which it's likely to be, we could well end up in bin 2. I think it will likely peak very soon, but it's not completely clear.
things appear to be inflecting up. Many states that have passed their initial delta peak (CA, MI, AS; Israel, UK too) seem to level off without dropping much, so shorting option A.
Misread the graph, the crowd is right about it having not dropped below 18.5 yet. Adjusting back. Still think it's likelier to have dropped before October 19 than have risen.

Thanks to @Ryan-Beck who pointed out that bin 2 is already gone, too. (Bins 2 and 4 are gone only thanks to the vagaries of Labor Day testing. It would have been more interesting to exclude those days!)
I expect cases to peak soon, if they haven't already, and then to remain lower than the Sept 7 level throughout the forecast period.

I should have accounted for the possibility of a labor day spike. I don't think a one day spike was the intent of the question though, so I'm leaving a small chance in each bucket in the event of a clarification that one day spikes don't count. It looks to me like low of 18.5 and the high of 28.5 were both passed in the 7 day moving average due to the Labor day blip. The crowd seems to disagree on it falling below 18.5 though, not sure why?
This might be too bold a forecast, and I might regret it.
I think there are reporting irregularities associated with Labor day that account for that spike, but I guess it's enough to eliminate option D.
Wow, big swing an a miss on my first forecast... Bin 4 is gone, on to Bin 3...

If cases peak 2 weeks from now and decline equally fast, cases would be lower on Oct. 19. But they may peak earlier or later, and the decline will likely be slower. Given that we're entering fall at high cases already, I don't think there's any realistic chance cases could fall below 18.5 in the forecast period. But stranger things have happened...
Perhaps cases will peak in the next couple weeks.
Currently looking flat out of Labor Day. Reducing likelihood of it hitting either of the reverse statuses (e.g drop then ends higher or rises and ends lower) as we run out of time.
sele I could be wrong because the cases are climbing in Mass. Going to have to see the general trend in the next couple of weeks.

The wastewater data shows a clear rounding off.
https://www.mwra.com/biobot/biobotdata.htm
Looking at UK curves and rethinking. I may be too optimistic.

Assumptions:
* No new variant that replaces Delta in the next 6 weeks.
* The majority of schools have started in late August or before Labor Day. Therefore most changes resulting from back to school (such as more testing or more cases) have already been seen, but we'll see some small additional increases.
* Vaccinations will continue to increase at a low rate, won't have a significant impact. Booster shots might start in late September, but since it takes about 7 days to have an impact, they will also have a minimal impact at reducing cases.
* The weather won't be too cold until mid October, so no increases due to winter.
* The number of cases reported depends on the number of cases and the number of tests. 
* The real number of cases has likely peaked. It is likely to start going down. I don't yet have high confidence on this.
* The number of tests might go up a bit due to school starts, and then probably stay flat or go down as cases stabilize / go down.
* There are no holidays that will have an artificial impact (less testing)
* Therefore:
- Bin 1 is very unlikely
- Bin 2 is not too likely, but might happen if the numbers haven't yet peaked. Need to track over the next few days.
- Bin 3 is unlikely.
- Bin 4 is the most likely

It looks as if cases have peaked, but I'm not quite convinced yet. MA has a relatively high proportion of fully vaccinated people (>67% overall), and the younger age groups (12-29yrs) average 68-71% for the first dose. However, Hampden and Bristol counties, which have some of the higher levels of cases, also have the lowest levels of vaccination, which suggests there is still scope for further transmission. Daily testing rates and positivity levels are fairly flat, but with schools and higher education open I think there could be slightly more testing over the next weeks, which could lead to flat or marginally increasing cases being recorded, before a decline starts to trend. 
So bin1 is almost ruled out; if case av. falls that low, it's unlikely to be reversed over the term
Bin2: I can't rule this out; Delta could still spread through younger groups, and the control week included a day with almost no cases recorded
Bin3: I think it would take a few weeks to hit 28.5 and that would signal that transmission is persisting, so this looks unlikely
Bin4: this looks the most likely with rising vaccination rates in younger ages, mask mandates, a plateauing chart. I'll go for a gradual rise for a few weeks, followed by a decline into October.
I may be going too far out on a limb here, but with how vaccinated MA is and that their Delta wave does seem to have peaked, I see a broad, slow, perhaps wavy decline through the forecast period.

As of the last info, the number is 15.4, so the option of “without having fallen below 18.5“ is impossible to hit (if I’ve read this right). Setting that to 0 and adding more likelihood to the other options, but especially below and remain below 28.5 as we are running out of time for a rise above 28.5

Vaccination rates have been fairly plateaued since about June, and I couldn't find any mentions of restrictions in recent news. With school starting and cooler weather, I'm leaning towards steady increase from here and not many downward forces (but I am not aware of how Mass. has responded to previous waves).
It will be after Delta, and before the Fall surge.

Massachusetts has the 3rd highest vaccination rate by state in the US, so that's a positive and should act as a buffer. https://www.beckershospitalreview.com/public-health/states-ranked-by-percentage-of-population-vaccinated-march-15.html The graph looks like it's plateaued but I've been fooled by that before. The UK chart peaked, fell back almost 50%, then started climbing again slowly (which is where we're at now) and 6 weeks is a long time in this world. When it peaked in the UK 69.6% had one and 54.6% had 2. In Ma 76% have 1 and 66.5% have 2. Delta should account for almost all cases now, so that factor should be steady. And it's unlikely another variant could become a factor in that timeframe. Cases would need to come up 20% over the timeframe to cross 28.5/100k... which I can't rule out. If it is at it's peak, and it follows the UK curve, it still shouldn't be above it's Sept 7 level in 6 weeks. This next week has a few important variables with schools back and and labour day festivities fueling the flames, the next week should be very telling. I could wait a week before making a forecast, but where's the fun in that...
Sept 7 case rate 23.4.  I think oct 19 will be lower.

MA has a pretty high vaccination rate and it seems like rates have leveled off elsewhere in the country. Overall I'm putting about 60% chance on no, and if yes occurs I think it looks at the moment like it's more likely to have happened in a second surge after levels drop down a bit. But I'll have to look back at this soon, Labor day does weird things to the numbers so it'll be better to see the trends after a few days have passed.

23.4 per 100k on Sep 7, 2021. And it looks to me like MA is near a peak of the Delta wave. I anticipate a slower decline of the Delta wave than its rise, because of spread in schools, seasonality starting to kick in, and some waning immunity; I think it's possible we could even see a second, lower peak at some point this fall. But I expect that overall, cases will be lower in the forecast period than they are now (with the small possibility of a slightly higher peak soon).
I 100% think that the answer will be bin 4, but I also 100% know it's best to hedge one's bets, at least a little.
Yo @paulm, @CJH, @jleibowich, @probahilliby, @Scappleby, an interesting question for you.
Some anecdotal info from local acquaintances about spread in afterschool programs, nudging bad case estimates up slightly.

75% of state is fully vaccinated already, continuing to go up https://usafacts.org/visualizations/covid-vaccine-tracker-states/state/massachusetts. https://covidestim.org/ estimates ~45% of population has already had COVID. Mathematically there is obviously overlap there, which means lots of folks have some immune protection, some with both. Also the curve now is peaking in MA (and nationally).  While there are breakthrough infections with Delta MA has a lot of immune protection reducing risk of infection.  We can compare to Israel, where we have a lot of noise about rise in Delta... (1) they are only at 62.5% of population fully vaccinated (younger population + a lot of folks not vaccinated) (2) Israel's prior spikes were late August September [and these things seem to be annual recurrence], (3) Israel was dealing with Delta for the first time. Delta has been dominant strain in US for awhile, seemingly is dropping already. In Massachusetts last year the winter climb started in October but didn't become exponential until December. Looking at the UK they hit peak end of July and still are below peak, even though it's climbed up from the trough too. https://ourworldindata.org/explorers/coronavirus-data-explorer?zoomToSelection=true&time=2020-03-01..latest&facet=none&pickerSort=asc&pickerMetric=location&Metric=Confirmed+cases&Interval=7-day+rolling+average&Relative+to+Population=true&Align+outbreaks=false&country=GBR~ISR~BEL~NLD

0.877 1 dose vaccination rate (12+)
(.052*2+.057)/15*12 = 0.1288 pop share <12
7.1M population (est.)
leaving approx. 7.1*.01288 + (1-0.877)(1-0.01288)*7.1 = 0.953M unvaccinated residents or 13.4% All time cases are at 771k, assuming no correlation between vaccination status and prior infection for simplicity.
Approx. 52k cases since delta, assume about half are in unvaccinated, so that leaves about 925k, then assume 13.4% of the remainder has had some form of covid & group with vaccinated (that's 124k) leaving about 800k with no immunity at all. Delta case rates have grown very slowly, around 4% daily. Likely they will continue to increase until some equilibrium point. I think we can simplify by assuming since vaccines are ~75% protective that ~25% of the vaccinated/prior covid population is susceptible, and adding the 800k with no vaccination or covid history gives 2.375M, less 52k cases leaves 2.325M susceptible. If cases increase at 4%/day until saturation, the rates (weekly) would look like
2020
2658
3498 A continued linear increase would lead to a rate on 10/19 of around 100k cases/day. This intuitively seems unlikely but at the same time, the infected population at that point is still so much smaller than the available susceptible group that it's not completely ridiculous. Looking at this another way - Alabama has an unvaccinated population of around 2M and has had around 150k infected since delta started to spread; with an unvaccinated population of around 1M, I'd expect at least 75k infections in Massachusetts before rates start to decline, which in the above calculation would be reached at the end of September, leaving about 3 weeks of decline back to 27-28 cases/day. If the increase goes slower, then this point will be reached later, so the case rate on 10/19 would be higher than 28. So in either analysis, the case rate would very likely rise above 28.5 cases/day, and not fall below the 9/7 number of 24. On the other hand, there is some chance that behavior changes like mask mandates could lead to a decreased rate of spread, and some chance that the above analysis is totally wrong, which I'm assigning about a 5% error margin split evenly over the remaining options.
